ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I have a much more refined definition of populism, which is used so broadly that it was difficult to put into context in political science previously.
I deepened my understanding of populism, its manifestations across the world, and its connection to democracy.

I learned all about populism. Its history, the conflicts over definitions, how to analyze it in historical and present context. But also the class made me think about all sorts of topics- democracy, sovereignty, education, etc. Also, it certainly helped teach me how to write a tight focused research paper.
Analyzing new frameworks, rejecting positivism.
I developed a deeper understanding of the concept of populism and have improved my discussion/debate skills with my peers.

I learned about the concept of populism--literature surrounding the topic, examples in the US and around the world, how populism need not be a negative phenomenon, and how the definition of populism is often undefined and disputed. I also learned more about what political science as an academic discipline includes and how to research/write papers in the social sciences.
Learned a lot not just about populism but also about academic discourse on political science topics and why it's important. Found It very cool

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I enjoyed the structure of the class primarily because we had a good level of discussion and active participation from everyone. I think that dynamic was very effective.
Professor Aslanidis is a fantastic professor and makes each weeks readings manageable and facilitates great discussions. No weaknesses in the course.

Strengths- Prof Aslanidis. Hes super super knowledgeable about so many things and also runs a very intentnional but laid back class.m that kept conversation super fun. Also many of the readings were really great.
Weaknesses- none in particular come to mind except for the fact that it took a bit to get discussion really in depth in the early weeks but I think thats expected

Professor Aslanidis is very engaging, and most of the readings are very interesting. However, he often leaves much of the guidance to the class, who, if they have not done the readings, will diverge from discussing some of the more interesting topics.

Interesting course content; I wish the readings were more focused and discussed in class--oftentimes, the readings were hard to engage with and class discussions seldom really required an understanding of the readings. I also wish that we could break down the tactics of populist leaders in more depth--more discussion of text analysis and the kinds of rhetoric we see in populist leaders would be helpful.
Professor Aslanidis makes this class super engaging and responsive to students.
Honestly just a great course overall. The readings are great and so were most of the discussions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!
I would recommend this class to another student because of the professor's ability to keep the students engaged in the material.
I would recommend this courseto any student interested in populism, spirited discussions about current political realities, or anyone looking for a good political science seminar.
100 percent if youre interested in populism or looking for a political science seminar that connects across many topics and disciplines. It was one of the best courses Ive taken at Yale
Yes! Very interesting course.

Yesespecially if you want to learn more about democratic and electoral processes, break down populist figures, and understand more about political science. This course is approachable even if you're not a student in the social sciences.
Yes. If you are curious about populism, Professor Aslanidis provides a comprehensive, broad, and deep dive into populism, its interpretations, and its iterations around the world.
Absolutely, in fact I did because I liked it a lot.
